name: Maternal oxygen administration for suspected impaired fetal growth

abstract.heading: Background
abstract.text: Fetal hypoxaemia is often a feature of fetal growth impairment. It has been suggested that perinatal outcome after suspected impaired fetal growth might be improved by giving mothers continuous oxygen until delivery.

abstract.heading: Objectives
abstract.text: The objective was to assess the effects of maternal oxygen therapy in suspected impaired fetal growth on fetal growth and perinatal outcome.

abstract.heading: Search methods
abstract.text: We searched the Cochrane Pregnancy and Childbirth Group's Trials Register (June 2009).

abstract.heading: Selection criteria
abstract.text: Acceptably controlled trials comparing maternal oxygen therapy with no oxygen therapy in suspected impaired fetal growth.

abstract.heading: Data collection and analysis
abstract.text: Eligibility and trial quality was assessed.

abstract.heading: Main results
abstract.text: Three studies involving 94 women were included. Oxygenation compared with no oxygenation was associated with a lower perinatal mortality rate (risk ratio 0.50, 95% confidence interval 0.32 to 0.81). However, higher gestational age in the oxygenation groups may have accounted for the difference in mortality rates.

abstract.heading: Authors' conclusions
abstract.text: There is not enough evidence to evaluate the benefits and risks of maternal oxygen therapy for suspected impaired fetal growth. Further trials of maternal hyperoxygenation seem warranted.

pls_title: Maternal oxygen administration for suspected impaired fetal growth
pls:
Too little evidence to show whether continuous oxygen therapy for pregnant women benefits babies in the womb who are smaller than expected.
Babies who receive too little oxygen from their mother's blood can grow more slowly than expected before birth (impaired fetal growth). With extreme lack of oxygen, the baby can die in the womb. Sometimes, it may be suggested that the mother breathe extra oxygen through a face mask 24 hours daily (oxygen therapy) until the baby's birth. The review of trials found that there is too little evidence to show whether the baby's growth improves when women have continuous oxygen therapy from mid-pregnancy until the baby's birth. There is some evidence that fewer babies may die, although further research is needed.
